seg.output: Peace and health through Jesus Christ. I give thanks to you for sending your exposition of John's epistle along with a prayer concerning the office of a prophet, not only for showing the affection of a friend towards me, but also for providing you with these new fruits and the best hope of all goods. You know who you have succeeded. Therefore, these first fruits are to be considered a testimony to the recently collapsed Christian republic. May Christ our Lord be with you, so that you may successfully execute what you have taken up, for the glory of God the Father and the edification of the whole church. Paul Riccius, the physician of Ferdinand, published this work with the favorable help of Ferdinand and the opposition of Faber. You will understand the cause and argument from the work itself. I wanted to send you a token of a friend's regard for you, even though I am a great ignorant of the learned. I also wanted to share this with Leo and Pellicanus, the brothers. He who sends you this is a minister of the church of Esslingen. From him you will hear how much Ambrose, our own, has promoted the kingdom of Christ. The Lord be with you. 6 April, Constance. Yours, John Zuick. I am sending two quaternions written by Luther to Leo, not to be published, but to be suppressed, as our cause is full of hatred. To the most accomplished man, Heinrich Bullinger, the apostle of the church of Zurich, his dearest brother.

seg.output:
Peace and health through Jesus Christ. I am grateful to you for sending me through a friend your exposition on John's Epistle with an added prayer on the office of a prophet. Not only do these attest a friendly spirit toward me, but they replenish your store with the best hope of all good things. You know well in whose place you have succeeded. These are therefore the first fruits at Zurich, a testimony for the restoration of the Christian Republic, recently collapsed with a great disaster. Therefore may Christ our Lord be with you, that you may happily accomplish what you have begun with the glory of God the Father and the edification of the entire Church.
Paul Riccius, a doctor of Ferdinand, published this book with the approval of Ferdinand and the opposition of Faber. You will understand the cause and argument from it. I wanted to send it to you as a token of a friend's spirit toward you, even though I am very unlearned but love the learned. You should also share it with the brothers Leoni and Pellicano. He who gives you these is a pastor of the church of Esslingen. From him you may hear how much our Ambrose has advanced the kingdom of Christ.
May the Lord be with you.
April 6th, Constance.
Your friend, John Zuick.
I am sending two quaternions written by Luther to Leoni, not to be published but to be suppressed, for our cause is full of hatred.
